reviewText: Really good history lesson regarding some of the positive actions taken place during the depression in the 1930s. It started out with a general description of the greed and selfishness of stockbrokers during the 1920s which led (in part) to the crash of 1929. Then, when I thought the next episodes would focus mainly on the desperate climate of the depression, they focused on 1) the Community Conservation Core, 2) the Hoover Dam, 3) the dust bowl, and finally 4) Seabiscuit. Admittedly, there was some depressing moments  especially during the dust bowl episode, but overall the episodes touched on very determined people who sacrificed themselves by building and re-shaping parts of the country that were overworked and destroyed primarily because of ignorance. I would recommend this to people that do not have a through understanding of events during the 1930s and to people who may want to rejuvenate their hopes that people are capable of incredible feats when they put their minds to it even during these trying times.

reviewText: With the recent crash of our economy and the markets, I thought it would be nice to refresh my memory of the Crash of 1929.  This is a good documentary explaining how too easy credit to buy stocks (you could buy stocks in those days with only 10% down), market manipulations and way too much speculation, despite a faltering economy in 1929, led to the crash. Stock prices then as today are driven by earnings.  When you see stock prices going up, but earnings flat or falling, you have your warning.  Something other than earnings is driving stock prices, and that something other is usually speculation.  I enjoyed the documentary.

reviewText: 1930's -- American ExperienceFascinating information that is thought provoking and offers a dramatic insight into a decade marked by the Great Depression. Questions answered and answers for questions you might not have considered. This series is well presented and gives a glimpse into everyday life as well as an open view of the federal government. A significant decade when this nation changed from neighbor helping neighbor sentiments to the necessary reforms that changed government policy. Follow the path from the crash of the stock market in 1929 to the race track. Seabiscuit was a remarkable Thoroughbred that came to be a symbol of resilience. The Crash of 1929, Creation of the Civilian Conservation Corp, Surviving The Dust Bowl, Building Hover Dam, and the entry of a horse named Seabiscuit. Each episode is well done and contains interviews and original footage. The narration is easy to follow and highlights the footage. A terrific find for one interested in US history. Extremely well presented and filled with accurate information!

reviewText: I grew up hearing my parents talk about the Great Depression from their perspective.  For my parents, who lived in Chicago at the time, their perspective was different from those who lived in agricultural areas.  The 1930's American Experience gave me a broader perspective of that era.  It is clear that the actions taken by the U.S. Government under Roosevelt was perhaps the most important aspect of the recovery.  Sadly that recovery was also aided by the onset of WWII.  In the episode describing the stock market crash  a scenario that is reminiscent of our recent market fluctuations is described.  In watching the series it is clear that the recovery only occurred when the employment rates rose significantly.  In the current era of global competition, out-sourcing and cheap labor the ability of the U.S. economy to rebound from a downturn may be more difficult.  Everyone should see this series no matter what your political convictions may be.
summary: 1930's Gives an Insight for the current generation to hopefully avoid a repeat of history.

reviewText: American Experience: The 1930's is an anthology of documentaries on DVD reflecting upon America's history during the turbulent 1930's, an era best known for the crushing impact of the Great Depression. Individual programs examine the stock market crash of 1929 and the dire consequences of unrestrained economic optimism; the creation of the Civilian Conservation Corps (including personal testimonies from CCC veterans), the story of the Hoover Dam that brought electricity and water to millions in the western U.S., the struggles of American farmers during the severe dust bowl "blizzards" of 1931, and even the remarkable accomplishments of the gifted thoroughbred Seabiscuit. Printable materials for educators round out this excellent and informative collection, ideal for public library DVD shelves. 5 DVDs, 4.5 hours. "The Civilian Conservation Corps" is also available as a stand-alone DVD.
summary: An excellent and informative collection, ideal for public library DVD shelves

reviewText: I almost did not buy this because of a negative review by a teacher.  However, I did get it and I'm glad.  My only negative is that it wasn't longer.  Five episodes make up the whole, all quite different but representative of the period.  I started with "Seabiscuit," the saga of the race horse who could, despite everything.  I proceeded to the episode about the Dust Bowl and concluded that it was something that Tea Baggers should watch and learn from  And so it went.The program has considerable depth, is well narrated and both educational and entertaining.  Pay no attention to the teacher's problems with it.

reviewText: This set has turned out to be better than I expected in its content.  The Stock Market Crash of 1929 was fairly well done, with interviews of descendents of the big financiers who took advantage of market conditions to manipulate stocks.  Perhaps more of the impact and influence of the U.S. market collapse on the world economy and a little less on the stock manipulators would have improved the presentation.The Dust Bowl segment is excellent and I have used it in my U.S. History classroom.  The rabbit scene captured the student's attention and broke up the dust storm sequences well.  Interviews with people who shared their childhood experiences in the Dust Bowl help to personalize the story.The Hoover Dam and Seabiscuit videos were also very good.I recommend the set in view of the fact that you get more video for the dollar.
